Orphans of the Storm (1921) is an American silent historical drama directed by pioneering filmmaker D.W. Griffith and starring the iconic Gish sisters, Lillian and Dorothy. This restored and colorized edition of a landmark public domain film breathes new life into a powerful story of love, sacrifice, and survival set against the backdrop of the French Revolution. Originally released during the peak of the silent film era, this ambitious epic combined sweeping spectacle with intimate human drama, influencing cinema for decades to come.

Plot Summary:
The story follows two sisters, Henriette (Lillian Gish) and Louise (Dorothy Gish), who live in rural France during the late 18th century. Louise is blind, and Henriette devotes herself to her care, embodying loyalty and devotion in a harsh world. Their lives are upended when they travel to Paris in search of a cure for Louiseâ€™s blindness. Fate cruelly intervenes when the sisters are separated amidst the turmoil of the French Revolution.

Henriette is kidnapped by the villainous aristocrat Marquis de Praille (Morgan Wallace) and thrown into a series of tragic ordeals. Meanwhile, Louise is left vulnerable in the chaotic streets of Paris, lost and destitute. Their individual struggles unfold as France itself descends into revolutionary violence, where mobs, guillotines, and political upheaval sweep through the nation.

Henrietteâ€™s fate becomes intertwined with that of Danton (Monte Blue), a revolutionary leader who represents both justice and the hope of a new society. The film climaxes with tense scenes of imprisonment, near-executions, and last-minute rescues that showcase Griffithâ€™s mastery of suspense and large-scale crowd sequences. Ultimately, the sistersâ€™ reunion serves as both a personal and symbolic victory â€” affirming themes of resilience, compassion, and survival in the face of tyranny.

Orphans of the Storm was one of D.W. Griffithâ€™s last major epics following The Birth of a Nation (1915) and Intolerance (1916). metadata.Plot: Henriette and Louise, a foundling, are raised together as sisters. When Louise goes blind, Henriette swears to take care of her forever. They go to Paris to see if Louise's blindness can be cured, but are separated when an aristocrat lusts after Henriette and abducts her. Only Chevalier de Vaudrey is kind to her, and they fall in love. The French Revolution replaces the corrupt Aristocracy with the equally corrupt Robespierre. De Vaudrey, who has always been good to peasants, is condemned to death for being an aristocrat, and Henriette for harboring him. Will revolutionary hero Danton, the only voice for mercy in the new regime, be able to save them from the guillotine?
